pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: InClass Ex 3
text:
Getting Started
Install and launch R packages
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse and ggiraph packages are installed in the computer.

pacman::p_load(ggiraph, tidyverse)

Importing the data



Plotting a simple bar chart






p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = ID),
    stackgroups = TRUE, 
    binwidth = 1, 
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 6,
  height_svg = 6*0.618
)

title: ISSS608
text: Welcome to my homepage. Let’s aim for A++

title: Hands-on Ex 1
text:
Creating data visualisation beyond default


















No.
Step
Action




1
Load excel file
Click to a file > choose excel file > Open.



2
Bin age group in 10s. Select down arrow > Create Group



3
Label bins and add selection to group



4
Separate the male and female population. Right click “Population” > Create > Calculated Field



5
Create a field “Male”.
Code: If [Sex] = “Males” THEN [Pop] END
Count the Males in the Population



6
Create a field “Females”.
Code: If [Sex] = “Males” THEN [Pop] END
Count the Females in the Population



7
Populate the Male and Female population in Columns by Age Group.
To create a pyramid, right click on Male>Edit Axis



8
a. Range > Fixed > End 24,000
To ensure Male and Female axis is synced.
b. Scale > Select Reversed



9
Show Top 9 Planning area.
Select down arrow key > Filter > Top > Top 9 > Pop Sum



10
Change colour of Female population.
Under SUM(Female) > Colour > Select Colour



11
Insert Avg Line per Planning Area



12
Publish on Tableau Public.
Sever > Tableau Public > Save to Tableau Public









This table allows for the user to easily compare each panel against the total average line (grey line). User can see clearly which areas are above average and below average.





It can be observed that even though the population chosen are the biggest 9 areas, the 9 areas are split into 4 above average, 2 on the line and 3 below average. There is a hug difference between the top and bottom of more than 5,000.



We observed that for the overall average, there are more females than males. This is also persistent in most planning areas with the exception of Jurong West and Woodlands. This can also be observed where in Sengkang and Jurong West, the female average is almost identical, JW had a larger male average, with a higher population for males aged 20-29.
This maybe because of the labour intensive job opportunities in that area which causes an increased demand for young males to move to that area.



We observed that in the following planning areas, there is a sharp dip in the population aged 40 - 49. The population for 50 then increases before it dips down again at 60.

Bukit Batok
Chua Chu Kang
Hougang
Tampines
Yishun
Woodlands (Males only)




For all top 9 planning areas, there are more females than males aged 89 and above. This is inline with research (https://www.prb.org/resources/around-the-globe-women-outlive-men/) that women have a longer life expectancy than men.



The planning areas Hougang and Yishun has the average population closest to the average line and thus would be an optimal area to do a population survey using these areas as statistical representation.



Interestingly, even though Punggol has the 2nd population, there is a large population of females 30 - 39 in that area. This is also interesting to note that for this particular area, the shape of the pyramid is asymmetrical. More research needs to be done to understand the reason.



With the exception of SengKang and Punggol, all other areas have a smaller base, indicating an aging population. This is consistent with Singapore projection. As SengKang and Punggol is a relatively new area, for BTOs of new couples, there are more babies born there.

title: Take Home Ex 2
text: SINGAPORE POPULATION DISTRIBUTION BY AGE by THOMAS HOANG

title: Take Home Ex 2
text:
Critic













Type
Critic
Description




Clarity
y-axis is by ascending order
In a standard pyramid, the y-axis should be by descending order, with 90&above at the top.



x-axis is inconsistent:
- between male & female in 1 planning area
-across all planning areas

x-axis should be consistent between male and female to show a comparative/symmetrical view of the pyramid (not be misleading)
x-axis should be consistent across all planning areas for ease of comparision




insufficient spacing for x-axis labels
User should be able to see the x-axis label clearly



no callouts or lead-in to provide context
No additional information is given to provide context


Aesthetics
Outline is distracting
The outline for each bar is distracting as there are many bars and the outline does not give any clarity



No gridelines
Missing grid lines for the x axis for ease of comparison



Distracting/ unclear colours
The yellow and purple colours are glaring for the eyes and is not normally associated with Male/Female (blue/pink)

title: Take Home Ex 2
text:
Remake

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, patchwork, ggthemes, reshape2, dplyr) 

#| echo: false
  Popdata <- read_csv("data/respopagesextod2022.csv", col_names = TRUE, show_col_types = FALSE)
Popdata

# A tibble: 100,928 × 7
   PA         SZ                     AG     Sex     TOD                Pop  Time
   <chr>      <chr>                  <chr>  <chr>   <chr>            <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   HDB 1- and 2-Ro…     0  2022
 2 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   HDB 3-Room Flats    10  2022
 3 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   HDB 4-Room Flats    10  2022
 4 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   HDB 5-Room and …    30  2022
 5 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   HUDC Flats (exc…     0  2022
 6 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   Condominiums an…    50  2022
 7 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   Landed Properti…     0  2022
 8 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males   Others               0  2022
 9 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Females HDB 1- and 2-Ro…     0  2022
10 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Females HDB 3-Room Flats     0  2022
# … with 100,918 more rows



PA_pop_tab <- Popdata %>%
  group_by(PA) %>%
  summarise(PA_pop = sum(Pop)) %>%
  top_n(n=9, wt=PA_pop) %>%
  arrange(desc(PA_pop))

PopdataT9 <- Popdata %>%
 filter(PA %in% PA_pop_tab$PA)


 Popdata_males <- Popdata %>%
  filter(`Sex` ==  "Males") %>%
  mutate (Pop = -Pop)
 
 Popdata_females <-Popdata %>%
  filter(`Sex` ==  "Females") 
Popdata_T <- rbind(Popdata_males,Popdata_females)

Popdata_T

# A tibble: 100,928 × 7
   PA         SZ                     AG     Sex   TOD                  Pop  Time
   <chr>      <chr>                  <chr>  <chr> <chr>              <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 1- and 2-Room…     0  2022
 2 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 3-Room Flats     -10  2022
 3 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 4-Room Flats     -10  2022
 4 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 5-Room and Ex…   -30  2022
 5 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HUDC Flats (exclu…     0  2022
 6 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males Condominiums and …   -50  2022
 7 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males Landed Properties      0  2022
 8 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males Others                 0  2022
 9 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 5_to_9 Males HDB 1- and 2-Room…     0  2022
10 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 5_to_9 Males HDB 3-Room Flats     -10  2022
# … with 100,918 more rows



options(scipen = 999)
ggplot(data = PopdataT9 , aes (y = PA, x = Pop, fill = Sex)) +
      geom_bar(stat = "identity") + scale_fill_manual("legend", values = c("Females" = "indianred1", "Males" = "royalblue3")) + scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + ggtitle("Total Population Size of Top 9 Planning Areas")





Popdata_T9 <- Popdata_T %>%
 filter(PA %in% PA_pop_tab$PA)


xbrks <- seq(-15000,15000,5000)
xlabls <- paste0(as.character(c(seq(15, 0, -5),seq(5,15,5))),"k")
Popdata_T$AG <- factor (Popdata_T$AG, levels = unique(Popdata_T$AG))

ggplot(Popdata_T9, aes (x = AG, y = Pop, fill = Sex)) +
      geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
      scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-15000,15000), breaks = xbrks, 
                         labels = xlabls, name = "Population Size")+  
  xlab("Age Groups") + coord_flip() + theme_bw() + facet_wrap(vars(PA)) +
  scale_fill_manual("legend", values = c("Females" = "indianred1", "Males" = "royalblue3")) + ggtitle("Population Pyramid of Top 9 Planning Areas")
